TopicTitle: List of Planetary Destinations Ranked by Delta V?

Articles.Content:
Has someone already compiled a ranking of planetary destinations according to delta v requirements? One including inclination delta v would be awesome. Most I've found don't include them.

Edited January 9, 2014 by inigma
Does anyone have such a list also including inclination delta v to their calculations? If you do I'll post it on the wiki.
Don't want to sound like a dick but just google "delta v map ksp".

I already have. I'm looking for one that takes into account inclination adjustment.

Edited January 9, 2014 by inigma

Don't want to sound like a dick but just google "delta v map ksp".

You aren't. I'm not looking for a dV map of which there are lots. I'm looking for a ranked list. I'm thinking someone has already compiled such a list so I dont have to reinvent the wheel.

It took a LOT of work as apparently this has not yet been done. So to share my effort so other's don't have to here is the list:

List of Closest Destinations to Kerbin Sorted by Maximum Delta V:

Values are from on http://i.imgur.com/NKZhU57.png and include maximum dV for inclination changes.

Edited January 12, 2014 by inigma

I've seen that delta-v map before and I'm sorry to say that while it is more accurate then the one used in the wiki it's still not entirely correct.

There is also the small matter of bodies with an atmosphere. While you may choose not to aero-brake and instead do a powered capture, there is simply no good way you're going to be able to spend as much delta-v going down as you do coming up (and coming up is what the delta-v chart is showing).

Just to help point out how important this is, consider the return values. Based on the chart it's 4500m/s to land on Kerbin which is what you've included. Even without parachutes it only takes a few hundred delta-v to land after you hit terminal velocity (mathematically you can deorbit and land for around 300m/s which I've done but it was for a challenge under very controlled conditions). This really throws off planets in the list like Eve where the chart has told you it takes 19380 m/s for a one way trip. With no aero-braking and no parachutes you can land on Eve for under 8000m/s starting from the surface of Kerbin. With those common aids it costs less then 6000 m/s.
any red arrow means aero-breaking possible therfore no deata-v required ...possibly it says that on the far right next to kerbin
Correct, the list is conservative and thus shows max values, not aerobraking possibilities. I should make a disclaimer.

In my tutorial I include lists for both orbiting and landing, including plane-change but ignoring aerobraking so the figures are high-ish:

"How hard is it to transfer to and orbit (from Kerbin, m/s)?" table

Mun 1,170

Minmus 1,430

Ike 1,550

Duna 1,700

Eve 2,880

Gilly 2,950

Dres 3,860

Tylo 3,860

Vall 3,890

Pol 4,040

Laythe 4,360

Eeloo 4,790

Jool 5,170

Bop 5,920

Moho 6,640

Kerbol 33,680

"How hard is it to transfer to, orbit then land (from Kerbin, m/s)?" table

Mun 1,750

Ike 1,940

Gilly 2,980

Duna 3,000

Pol 4,170

Dres 4,290
